articleinfo.title: &app; Manual

abstract.para: &app; is a simple backup system for GNOME desktop.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a simple backup system for Linux (Gnome and KDE4). The backup is done by taking snapshots of a specified set of directories.
All you have to do is configure:

listitem.para: when backup should be done (manual, every hour, every day, every week, every month, ...)

sect1.para: &app; acts as a "user mode" backup system. This means that you can backup/restore only folders you have write access to (actually you can backup read-only folders, but you can't restore them).
A new snapshot is created only if something changed since the last snapshot (if any).

A snapshot contains all the files from the selected directories (except for exclude patterns). In order to reduce disk space it use hard\-links (if possible) between snapshots for unchanged files. This way a file of 10Mb, unchanged for 10 snapshots, will use only 10Mb on the disk.
When you restore a file 'A', if it already exists on the file system it will be renamed to 'A.backup.currentdate'.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para:
Choose
System Tools Back In Time .
To start &app; from a command line, type the following command, then press Return:

path - go directly to the specified file or directory. If the application is already running if pass the path to the running instance. If the main window is not the only window (there is already a dialog) the parameter is ignored.

-s, --snapshots - go directly to the specified file or directory and show snapshots dialog. If the application is already running if pass the path to the running instance. If the main window is not the only window (there is already a dialog) the parameter is ignored.
-h, --help - display a small help and exit.

sect1.title: Main Window
sect1.para: The Back In Time main window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: Snapshots: show all snapshots for current the file/directory
Quickly navigate to special folders: home, root, bookmarks and directories to backup
Navigate through the file system at the moment specified in timeline list.
You can sort the files (by clicking on column headers):
If you double-click a file it will be opened using gnome file association. Keep in mind that snapshots are 'readonly'.
If you double-click a directory it will go to that directory.
If you "right-click" on a file or directory you will see a popup-menu

itemizedlist.listitem: Open: open the item using gnome-open
Copy: copy selected item into clipboard (you can paste the file/directory into your file-manager)
Snapshots: show all snapshots for the current file/directory
Restore (only for snapshots items): restore selected file/directory

sect1.title: Settings Dialog
sect1.para: When the application starts for the first time (not configured yet) this dialog is displayed automaticaly.

listitem.para: Define the directories you want to backup. From this directories you can exclude some files/directories using exclude pattern. By default it exclude hidden (".*") and "*.backup*" files/directories.

Values: none (default), every 5 minutes, every 10 minutes, every hour, every day, every week, every month. If your backup directory is on a removable drive (ex: usb-drive) it is recommended to set automatic backup to none and take manual snapshots when the drive is plugged.
Automatic backup use cron jobs so cron must be running.
You can automatically remove snapshots older then a specific date or if the free space is less then a specified value.
By default it does not remove named snapshots.

sect1.title: Snapshots Dialog
sect1.para: Show all snapshots for a specific file or directory.
Double-click an item in the snapshots list to open it with gnome file associations.
When you select an item, you can:

itemizedlist.listitem: Jump to: close the dialog an go to the selected snapshot in the main window

sect1.para: You can compare two different snapshots. By default it use 'meld' to compare files adn directories. Use diff options to change the diff command and it's parameters.
If you "right-click" on a snapshot you will see a popup-menu

itemizedlist.listitem: Open: open the item using gnome-open
Copy: copy selected item into clipboard (you can paste the file/directory into your file-manager)
Jump to: close the dialog an go to the selected snapshot in the main window
Restore (only for snapshots): restore selected file/directory
Diff: compare it with another snapshot
